Introduction

Mumps is a vaccine-preventable disease caused by a single-stranded RNA paramyxovirus, typically manifesting with fever, malaise, myalgia, and parotid swelling.  Mumps is uncommon due to widespread vaccination, but outbreaks can occur among unvaccinated populations.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The mumps virus is highly infectious and spreads via contact with respiratory droplets, saliva, or fomites.  The incubation period ranges from 7-21 days; however, viral shedding begins prior to the onset of symptoms, leading to widespread transmission.  Once contracted, the mumps virus replicates in respiratory mucosal epithelium and lymphatic tissue, leading to viremia and systemic infection.



Risk factors for mumps include being unvaccinated and in close contact with infected individuals.  Outbreaks are more common in settings where people live closely together, such as college campuses.

Clinical presentation



Mumps is most common among unvaccinated children age 2-9, who often have mild disease or are asymptomatic.  After the incubation period, patients typically develop nonspecific symptoms (eg, fever, headache, myalgias) (

figure 1
).  Fatigue and anorexia are also common.  The virus has an affinity for glandular epithelium, and within 48 hours of onset of the nonspecific prodrome, salivary gland inflammation occurs.



Parotitis most commonly occurs in young children and may be unilateral or bilateral.  If bilateral, patients typically develop unilateral symptoms initially (eg, tenderness, swelling), followed by contralateral symptoms within 2-3 days.  Pain may radiate to the ear, and salivary gland tenderness typically self-resolves before swelling, which can last 7-10 days.

Complications



Complications are more likely among unvaccinated adolescents and adults and include (

figure 2
):



  • Genitourinary:  orchitis, oophoritis (hypogonadism, infertility)
  • Neurologic:  meningitis, encephalitis, transverse myelitis, hearing loss (often transient but can lead to deafness)


Orchitis is most common and occurs 5-10 days after the onset of parotitis with fever and severe testicular pain.  The scrotum may appear erythematous and edematous.  Although rare, residual seminiferous tubule atrophy can cause infertility, and Leydig cell atrophy can cause decreased testosterone production.  Oophoritis is much less common and has been associated with primary ovarian insufficiency; its association with infertility is unknown.



Aseptic meningitis is the most common neurologic complication and typically presents with fever, headache, and mild nuchal rigidity.  Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows elevated white blood cell count (pleocytosis), elevated protein concentration, and normal glucose concentration.  Most patients have a full recovery after the episode.



Other rare complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of mumps is primarily clinical, based on history and physical examination.  Common physical examination findings include swelling of the parotid gland that obscures the angle of the mandible.  The opening of the parotid duct (Stenson duct) may appear erythematous, but purulent discharge is not common.  Laboratory confirmation can be obtained through serological testing or reverse-transcriptase PCR testing of oral swabs.

Differential diagnosis



Other disorders may have overlapping clinical features with mumps:



  • Parotitis (eg, viral, bacterial, noninfectious)

    • Other viral etiologies include adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, and Epstein-Barr virus.  Similar to mumps, these conditions present with a viral prodrome followed by salivary gland swelling that lasts 5-10 days.
    • Bacterial parotitis is typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus and presents with acute parotid gland swelling, erythema, and tenderness without a prodromal period.  In addition, purulent discharge is often expressed from the parotid duct, which helps distinguish bacterial from viral parotitis.
    • Noninfectious causes include an obstructive salivary gland stone or tumor, SjÃ¶gren syndrome, or sarcoidosis.
  • Epididymoorchitis (eg, viral, bacterial)
    • Other viral etiologies include rubella, coxsackie, and parvovirus.
    • Bacterial epididymoorchitis is typically caused by sexually transmitted infections (eg, Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae) as well as enteric organisms (eg, Escherichia coli).

Management



Management of mumps is supportive with a focus on relieving symptoms (eg, analgesics, warm compresses for parotitis).  The prognosis for uncomplicated mumps is favorable; symptoms typically resolve within 1-2 weeks.  However, patients should be monitored closely for complications (eg, orchitis, aseptic meningitis), particularly in unvaccinated adolescents and adults.

Prevention



The most effective strategy for the prevention of mumps is immunization prior to exposure.  The measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine is a live-attenuated combined vaccine routinely administered at age 1 and again at age 4.  It is safe and effective, with mild reactions (eg, fever, rash, transient lymphadenopathy) occurring in only a minority (3%-5%) of immunized patients.  Vaccination is contraindicated in patients with severe immunodeficiency or in pregnancy.  Vaccination has not been shown to prevent infection if administered following exposure to mumps.

Prognosis



Mumps is typically a benign, self-limited illness that usually has a good prognosis; however, some patients can develop sequelae.



Patients who develop orchitis with Leydig cell atrophy may require exogenous testosterone to alleviate hypogonadal symptoms (eg, fatigue, loss of libido); however, fertility cannot be restored.  Patients who develop aseptic meningitis are at risk for sensorineural hearing loss and require hearing screening.

Summary
